name: adtl
brief:
Tape-less (traceless) forward-mode automatic differentiation

Provides the adtl::adouble class for direct forward-mode AD without
tape recording. Each adouble carries both its value and directional
derivatives, which are propagated immediately through operations.

algorithms.name:
Memory Trade-off:
Tapeless vs. tape-based comparison.

  TAPELESS:
    Memory: O(n_active · p) where n_active = live variables, p = #directions
    No tape overhead, no storage of operation sequence
    Best for: few directions, simple control flow

  TAPE-BASED:
    Memory: O(operations) for tape + O(n) per evaluation
    Supports reverse mode: O(1) directions for gradient
    Best for: many directions, need reverse mode
algorithms.math:
For function y = f(x) with seed vectors s_i:
  adval[i] = ∇f(x)ᵀ s_i (directional derivative in direction s_i)
  With s_i = e_i (standard basis), get ∇f component-wise.
algorithms.complexity:
Per operation: O(p) for p directions
Total function evaluation: O(operations · p)
Gradient via p=n directions: O(n · operations)

Advantages over tape-based mode:
- No memory overhead from tape storage
- Lower per-operation cost for simple functions
- Simpler for computing few directional derivatives

Limitations:
- Only forward mode (no reverse/adjoint mode)
- Memory scales as O(n·p) for n variables and p directions
- Must set numDir before creating adoubles via setNumDir(p)

see: adtb_types.h for tape-based adouble (supports reverse mode)
